author: Bahá'u'lláh
source_text:
(من الواح عيد الرضوان) بسمه المجلّي على من في الإمكان يا قلم الأعلى قد أتى ربيع البيان بما تقرّب عيد الرحمن
بِسْمِهِ الْمُجَلِّي عَلَى مَنْ فِي الإِمْكَانِ
يَا قَلَمَ الأَعْلَى قَدْ أَتَى رَبِيعُ الْبَيَانِ بِمَا تَقَرَّبَ عِيدُ الرَّحْمنِ قُمْ بَيْنَ مَلإِ الإِنْشَاءِ بِالذِّكْرِ وَالثَّنَاءِ عَلَى شَأْنٍ يُجَدَّدُ بِهِ قَمِيصُ الإِمْكَانِ وَلا تَكُنْ مِنَ الصَّامِتِينَ، قَدْ طَلَعَ نَيِّرُ الابْتِهَاجِ مِنْ أُفُقِ سَمَآءِ اسْمِنَا الْبَهَّاجِ بِمَا تزَيَّنَ
translation: The Divine Springtime is come, O Most Exalted Pen, for the Festival of the All-Merciful is fast approaching. Bestir thyself, and magnify, before the entire creation, the name of God, and celebrate His praise, in such wise that all created things may be regenerated and made new. Speak, and hold not thy peace. The daystar of blissfulness shineth above the horizon of Our name, the Blissful, inasmuch as the kingdom of the name of God hath been adorned with the ornament of the name of thy Lord, the Creator of the heavens. Arise before the nations of the earth, and arm thyself with the power of this Most Great Name, and be not of those who tarry.

terms.note: Ṣamt typically 'silence' or 'silent' across 4 occurrences; imperative form 'hold not thy peace' converts nominal concept into active suppression of speech, amplifying the call to utterance beyond root sense.

Zayn consistently 'adorned' or 'adornment' across 29 occurrences; SE maintains expected rendering, but applies it to kingdom of divine name—creating paradox of embellishment applied to transcendent reality.
